title: International tourist arrivals grew 5% in Q1 2025
snippet: International tourist arrivals (overnight visitors) increased by 5% in the first quarter of 2025 though results were mixed among regions and sub-regions.
claim: International tourist arrivals grew 5% in Q1 2025
supporting_text: International tourist arrivals (overnight visitors) increased by 5% in the first quarter of 2025 though results were mixed among regions and sub-regions.

title: UN Tourism World Tourism Barometer | Global Tourism Statistics
snippet: International tourist arrivals (overnight visitors) increased by 5% in the first quarter of 2025 (compared to the same period in 2024), or 3% above pre-pandemic year 2019. Around 300 million tourists travelled internationally in Q1 2025, about 14 million more than in the period of 2024.
claim: UN Tourism World Tourism Barometer | Global Tourism Statistics
supporting_text: International tourist arrivals (overnight visitors) increased by 5% in the first quarter of 2025 (compared to the same period in 2024), or 3% above pre-pandemic year 2019. Around 300 million tourists travelled internationally in Q1 2025, about 14 million more than in the period of 2024.

title: UN Tourism | Bringing the world closer

title: International Tourist Arrivals Grew 5% in Q1 2025 - Hospitality Net
snippet: According to the May 2025 **World Tourism Barometer from UN Tourism**, over **300 million tourists travelled internationally in the first three months of 2025**, about 14 million more than in the same months of 2024. Available data on international tourism receipts for Q1 2025 shows solid growth in visitor spending in many destinations: Revised data shows that total export revenues from international tourism (receipts and passenger transport) grew by 11% (real terms) to reach a record USD 2.0 trillion in 2024, about 15% above pre-pandemic levels. The latest Panel of Tourism Experts survey points to economic factors including weaker economic growth, high travel costs and the increase in tariffs as the main three challenges that could impact international tourism in 2025.
claim: International Tourist Arrivals Grew 5% in Q1 2025 - Hospitality Net
supporting_text: According to the May 2025 **World Tourism Barometer from UN Tourism**, over **300 million tourists travelled internationally in the first three months of 2025**, about 14 million more than in the same months of 2024. Available data on international tourism receipts for Q1 2025 shows solid growth in visitor spending in many destinations: Revised data shows that total export revenues from international tourism (receipts and passenger transport) grew by 11% (real terms) to reach a record USD 2.0 trillion in 2024, about 15% above pre-pandemic levels. The latest Panel of Tourism Experts survey points to economic factors including weaker economic growth, high travel costs and the increase in tariffs as the main three challenges that could impact international tourism in 2025.

title: Tourism Surges 5% in 2025, Overwhelming Popular Destinations
snippet: - Global tourism surged 5% in Q1 2025, surpassing 2019 levels, driven by "revenge travel" post-pandemic. Tourism has surged beyond prepandemic levels, overwhelming popular destinations worldwide. France, a top tourist destination, saw its travel and tourism sector contribute 10.1% more to its national GDP in 2024 than in 2019. For instance, in Spain’s 25 most popular coastal destinations, hotel prices have risen by 23% in the past three years, while foreign tourism increased by 1.94 million people and local tourism dropped by 800,000. Italy imposed a five-euro tax on tourists traveling into Venice for day trips to mitigate tourism at the UNESCO World Heritage Site. The World Travel and Tourism Council predicts that international spending will rise to $87.3 billion in 2025.
claim: Tourism Surges 5% in 2025, Overwhelming Popular Destinations
supporting_text: - Global tourism surged 5% in Q1 2025, surpassing 2019 levels, driven by "revenge travel" post-pandemic. Tourism has surged beyond prepandemic levels, overwhelming popular destinations worldwide. France, a top tourist destination, saw its travel and tourism sector contribute 10.1% more to its national GDP in 2024 than in 2019. For instance, in Spain’s 25 most popular coastal destinations, hotel prices have risen by 23% in the past three years, while foreign tourism increased by 1.94 million people and local tourism dropped by 800,000. Italy imposed a five-euro tax on tourists traveling into Venice for day trips to mitigate tourism at the UNESCO World Heritage Site. The World Travel and Tourism Council predicts that international spending will rise to $87.3 billion in 2025.
